CO2 is a greenhouse gas due to how it interacts with different
wavelengths of radiation. This is a property of physics and can be
shown mathematically or it can be demonstrated in real time in a lab.
So when we say that CO2 is a greenhouse gas, it's a statement of
fact. 

The problem is that the radiation coming in isn't blocked but the
radiation going out is, which reflects it back into the planet adding
energy. Adding energy to a system will increase the temperature. 

No models, no projections, no big mean science organization that
you don't trust, this is just reality.

The increase in CO2 levels is due to human activity. We know this
because they have increased significantly and, from a geological
scale, very quickly since the start of the industrial revolution. We
are able to tell the difference between natural sources, such as
volcanic activity and the decay of organic matter, and human created
sources, such as the burning of fossil fuels. 

No models, no projections, no big mean science organizations that
you don't trust, this is just reality.
